title: Jacob Rees-Mogg and Diane Abbott among MPs harassed during Super Saturday
text:
Jacob Rees-Mogg with his son Peter Theodore Alphege being escorted by police officers during an anti-Brexit rally (Picture: PA)

MPs on both sides of the Brexit divide had to have police escorts to help navigate hecklers showering them with abuse after Parliament voted to frustrate Boris Johnson’s Brexit plans yesterday.

Arch Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg and Remain-backing Diane Abbott were among those surrounded as they walked through Westminster yesterday, the first Saturday sitting of Parliament in a generation to debate leaving the EU.

The scenes were repeated as leading Conservative MPs Andrea Leadsom and Michael Gove were also subjected to angry verbal abuse.

Cries of ‘traitor’ ‘and ‘shame on you’ were hurled at Commons leader Mr Rees-Mogg, who had brought his eldest son Peter Theodore Alphege, 12, with him to work.

They were bombarded as they walked to their Westminster home as up to a million people marched to call for whatever deal is finally agreed upon to be put to the public in a ‘people’s vote’.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Reacting to the scenes she witnessed, Mrs Leadsom praised the efforts of the Met officers who helped her.

She wrote online: ‘Thank goodness for our superb police. Just walked home safely from HoC with their protection – why do the so called ‘People’s Vote’ protesters think it’s ok to abuse, intimidate and scream in the face of someone they don’t agree with?

‘So frightening, and so grateful to the police.’

Flanked by police Michael Gove not answering questions about the vote pic.twitter.com/YX2gbieWR6 — Jason Farrell (@JasonFarrellSky) October 19, 2019

Mr Gove was given similar treatment until passing a police cordon, although this didn’t stop him from taking questions from journalists.

MPs were recalled to Westminster on Saturday and voted through an amendment to Boris Johnson’s Brexit proposal which in effect stops any loopholes that would have allowed a no-deal crash out Brexit to sneak through.

Essentially, if Parliament had approved Mr Johnson’s deal yesterday there was still the chance legislation needed to enact it would not have been in place in time to avoid the 31 October cliff edge.

That now can not happen after MPs voted 322 to 306 in favour of the Letwin amendment – and forced the Prime Minister to write to the EU requesting an extension to the process.

Meanwhile Labour shadow home secretary Diane Abbott was accosted by Tommy Robinson associate Daniel Thomas, also known as Danny Thomo.

Police escorting @HackneyAbbott as she is harassed by pro-Brexit supporters after leaving the stage of the #PeoplesVoteMarch pic.twitter.com/0plDF0HyF1 — Stéphanie Bosset (@39_stephs) October 19, 2019

Advertisement

Advertisement

Mr Thomas, a far-right activist who was imprisoned in 2016 for attempted kidnap, held a camera to Ms Abbott as she was escorted away from the People’s March protest telling her to ‘go on a long holiday with Jeremy Corbyn and stay there’.

He also tried to engage with Labour MP David Lammy and said he was also waiting to speak with London Mayor Sadiq Khan.

Mr Rees-Mogg said the Government was planning to give MPs a fresh chance to have a ‘meaningful vote’ on the deal hammered out by Mr Johnson with Brussels on Monday.

Speaker John Bercow said he would rule on Monday whether it was in order for the Government to hold the vote, after not pressing ahead with it on Saturday following its defeat on the Letwin amendment.

description: Politicians slammed a group of People’s Vote protesters who 'abused' the Commons leader as he walked with his 12-year-old son.
